capabilities.value: Tests 15 sample materials (fabrics, paint coatings, optical systems, sensors, solar cells), CCD camera detection system measures dust adherence and accumulation rates during landing and surface operations, exposed sample carrier disc, materials include Kapton HN (127 μm thick polyimide film), Teflon FEP (508 μm thick fluoropolymer), carbon fiber reinforced bismaleimide composite (Cycom 5250-1 resin, Toray M30S fabric), Ti-6Al-4V titanium alloy, operated one lunar day (14 Earth days), quantifies dust tenacity for spacecraft/spacesuit/habitat design
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified from NASA NTRS technical paper and NASA CLPS site. Four materials detailed in NTRS paper (Kapton HN, Teflon FEP, BMI composite, Ti-6Al-4V), plus 11 additional materials for 15 total. CCD camera system images dust accumulation. Successfully operated March 2-16, 2025 on Blue Ghost 1.

items.notes: Aegis Aerospace (formerly Alpha Space Test & Research Alliance), Webster, TX. Sample carrier disc exposed before landing. Deployed March 2, 2025 on Blue Ghost 1, operated 14 days. Measures lunar dust adhesion tenacity to inform Artemis program material selection for spacecraft, spacesuits, habitats, equipment protection. First fully successful CLPS mission.

items.model: ESCC Qualified Pt Thin-Film Temperature Sensors
items.description: ESCC qualified thin-film platinum RTD temperature sensors for space applications

trl.verification_notes: Verified TRL 9. ESCC qualified February 2018 after 4 years evaluation/qualification by ESA. Flight proven on multiple space missions: Juice, Solar Orbiter, Euclid, LISA, MPCV, ARIEL, Space Reaction Wheels, ERSA, EAGLE, IMAP, SABIAMAR, TITAN, ROSE-L, Comet Interceptor, SOLAR-C. Only platinum temperature sensors with ESA ESCC qualification. IST AG vendor site.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Verified 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.1 mm dimensions from IST AG vendor site. Mass ~11 mg (0.000011 kg) estimated from dimensions and thin-film construction. Described as 'light weight' for space applications.

power_kw.verification_notes: No power consumption - passive resistive RTD (Resistance Temperature Detector). Requires external measurement circuit but sensor itself is unpowered. 2/3/4-wire configurations available.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Commercial vendor, pricing not published. Contact required for quote. Available as flight models (FM) and engineering models (EM).

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Commercial off-the-shelf ESCC qualified product.

capabilities.value: Temperature range -200°C to +200°C, Pt100 to Pt2000 resistance values, 2/3/4-wire configurations, 70,000 thermal cycles tested (-200°C to +200°C, equivalent to ISS circumnavigating Earth 16x/day for 20 years), drift-stable TCR, thin-film platinum RTD on ceramic substrate, dimensions 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.1 mm, ESCC spec 4006/015, wire extensions also ESCC qualified
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified from IST AG vendor site. Only ESCC qualified platinum temperature sensors (ESA standard). Recertified for continued space use. Excellent thermal cycle performance with negligible TCR drift. Wire extensions also ESCC qualified. Multiple space missions flown.

items.notes: IST AG (Innovative Sensor Technology), Switzerland. ESCC qualified Feb 2018, only platinum sensors with ESA qualification. Flight heritage: Juice, Solar Orbiter, Euclid, LISA, MPCV, ARIEL, IMAP, Comet Interceptor, SOLAR-C, others. Thin-film Pt RTD, passive sensor. 2.2x2.0x1.1mm, ~11mg.

items.description: NASA GSFC qualified epoxy-encapsulated precision interchangeable NTC thermistors for extended space flight

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 from Electronic Design article documenting flight heritage on Juno mission (2011 launch, Jupiter arrival 2016) and Pioneer 10 (1970s). TE Connectivity has supplied NASA-qualified thermistors for 40+ years since mid-1970s. NASA GSFC S-311-P-18 qualified, on NASA QPLD. Note: Vendor site (te.com) blocked automated access (WebFetch and Puppeteer both failed with protocol errors).

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Dimensions are 2.4-2.8 mm diameter, indicating very small mass (likely <1 gram). Checked NASA S-311-P-18 spec and TE sources but exact mass not specified.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not applicable - passive resistive sensor, no active power required. NTC thermistors operate by resistance change with temperature.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. NASA-qualified components typically require RFQ. Checked distributor sites (CDI, Variohm) but pricing not listed.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Line requalified yearly per MIL-PRF-23648, suggesting ongoing production availability.

capabilities.value: Temperature range -55°C to +150°C (with excursion limits), ±0.1°C or ±0.2°C interchangeability (0-70°C), 2.4-2.8mm diameter, high sensitivity, long-term stability, <0.66% TML, <0.01% CVCM outgassing (ASTM E-595-90)
capabilities.verification_notes: Confirmed from TE Connectivity official whitepaper 'Sensors in Space' and NASA S-311-P-18 specification references. Temperature excursions: ±0.2°C units can go to 150°C, ±0.1°C units to 100°C. Dimensions and outgassing specs confirmed from multiple sources including NASA NEPP documentation.

items.notes: Line requalified yearly per MIL-PRF-23648. Fully flight tested and characterized. Thermally conductive epoxy coating.

items.description: Temperature probe with controlled penetration measuring thermal gradient to 10cm depth

trl.verification_notes: Verified TRL 9. Successfully deployed on Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander: launched July 14, 2023, landed August 23, 2023 at lunar south pole (69.37°S). First observations recorded August 27, 2023. Operated for one lunar day (~10 Earth days, Aug 24-Sept 4, 2023). Mission fully successful achieving all primary objectives. eoPortal and ISRO official sources.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Verified 2.5 kg total mass including probe and harness from Space Physics Laboratory (SPL) VSSC official site, the developing organization.

power_kw.verification_notes: Verified 35W maximum power allocation (0.035 kW) from SPL VSSC official site. Custom capton foil heater for thermal conductivity measurements in active mode.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. ISRO government space mission instrument.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable. ISRO technology, commercial availability uncertain.

capabilities.value: Ten Pt-1000 RTD temperature sensors positioned at 1 cm intervals, controlled penetration mechanism to 10 cm depth (achieved 14 cm penetration on mission), rotation-based deployment (not hammering), syntactic foam composite probe (cyanate ester/urethane-modified epoxy with glass fiber and cork), natural frequency >120 Hz stowed, passive mode vertical thermal gradient measurement, active mode thermal conductivity estimation via heating, measured surface temperature 355K (±0.5K) vs predicted 330K, operated ~150 hours covering 8AM-4PM lunar time
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified from SPL VSSC official site (developing organization) and ISRO official mission pages. First in-situ measurement of lunar subsurface temperature profile at southern high latitudes. Temperature measurements taken at 1-second intervals across 10 depths up to 100mm (achieved 140mm).

items.notes: Developed by Space Physics Laboratory (SPL) VSSC in collaboration with Physical Research Laboratory (PRL) Ahmedabad. Part of Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander payload. Successfully operated at lunar south pole (69.37°S, 32.35°E) from Aug 23 - Sept 4, 2023. First-ever in-situ thermal measurements of Moon's topmost fluffy layer at high southern latitudes. Entered sleep mode Sept 4, 2023 after one lunar day; revival attempts Sept 22, 2023 unsuccessful due to harsh lunar night (-180°C).

items.description: Seismometer for detecting moonquakes around landing site

trl.verification_notes: Verified TRL 9. Successfully deployed on Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander: landed August 23, 2023 at lunar south pole (69.37°S). Operated Aug 24 - Sept 4, 2023 (one lunar day). Recorded vibrations from rover movements (Aug 25, 2023) and detected potential natural seismic event (Aug 26, 2023) under investigation. First MEMS-based seismometer on Moon. First seismic data from lunar polar region. eoPortal and ISRO official sources.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Verified 1.8 kg mass, dimensions 17.0 x 17.0 x 7.2 cm from eoPortal and technical search results. Confirmed in multiple sources including scientific literature.

power_kw.verification_notes: Verified power consumption less than 4W (0.004 kW) from eoPortal and technical search results.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. ISRO government space mission instrument.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable. ISRO technology, commercial availability uncertain.

capabilities.value: Six high-sensitivity MEMS accelerometers (indigenously fabricated via Silicon micromachining), spring-mass system with comb-structured electrodes, dynamic range ±0.5 g, resolution 100 nano-g/Hz^1/2, bandwidth 40 Hz, capacitance-based sensing (vibration deflects mass changing electrode capacitance converted to voltage), measures moonquakes, impacts, and artificial events, characterizes lunar crust and mantle structure, first MEMS instrument on Moon, first seismic data from lunar polar region
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified from ISRO official site and eoPortal. Developed at Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems (LEOS) Bangalore with private industry support. Deployment mechanism by U.R. Rao Satellite Centre Bengaluru. Recorded rover movements and potential natural moonquake during mission.

items.notes: Developed by Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems (LEOS) Bangalore with private industry support. Deployment mechanism by U.R. Rao Satellite Centre (URSC) Bengaluru. Part of Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander payload. First Indian seismometer on lunar surface and first MEMS-based seismometer on Moon. Successfully operated Aug 23 - Sept 4, 2023. Recorded rover movements (Aug 25) and potential natural seismic event (Aug 26) under investigation. Entered sleep mode Sept 4, 2023; revival attempts Sept 22, 2023 unsuccessful.

items.model: RAMBHA-LP (Radio Anatomy of Moon Bound Hypersensitive ionosphere and Atmosphere - Langmuir Probe)
items.description: Plasma density measurement probe for lunar surface environment

trl.verification_notes: Verified TRL 9. Successfully deployed on Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander: landed August 23, 2023 at lunar south pole (69.37°S, 32.35°E). Operated Aug 23 - Sept 4, 2023. First measurements August 31, 2023. Measured electron density 5-30 million electrons/m³ initially, later refined to 380-600 electrons/cm³ at Shiv Shakti point. Electron temperatures 3,000-8,000 Kelvin. First in-situ plasma measurements at lunar south pole. eoPortal and ISRO official sources.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Verified 1.3 kg total mass for RAMBHA-LP system from eoPortal and technical search results. Includes 5 cm spherical probe, 1 m CFRP boom, deployment mechanism, and electronics.

power_kw.verification_notes: Power consumption not published. DSP-based controller with bipolar ADC. Checked SPL VSSC official site and multiple sources - no power specification found.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. ISRO government space mission instrument.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable. ISRO technology, commercial availability uncertain.

capabilities.value: Spherical Langmuir probe 5 cm diameter with Titanium Nitride coating, CFRP boom ~1 m length, sweep potential ±12V in 0.1V steps, 60 ms dwell time per step, detects pico-ampere currents with 1 ms response time, measures ion and electron densities and energies, DSP-based controller with bipolar ADC, spring-assisted deployment mechanism, dust protection enclosure, shape-memory alloy hold-release mechanism, measured electron density 380-600 electrons/cm³, electron temperature 3,000-8,000K, detected molecular ions (CO₂, H₂O-derived), monitors solar wind and magnetotail interactions
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified from ISRO official site and SPL VSSC official page. Developed by Space Physics Laboratory (SPL) VSSC Thiruvananthapuram. First in-situ lunar south pole plasma measurements. Revealed higher electron densities than orbital observations predicted, identified molecular ion contributions to charged environment.

items.notes: Developed by Space Physics Laboratory (SPL) Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) Thiruvananthapuram. Part of Chandrayaan-3 Vikram lander payload. Mounted on top deck of lander. Successfully operated Aug 23 - Sept 4, 2023 at Shiv Shakti point (69.3°S, 32.3°E). First Langmuir probe measurements at lunar south polar region. Provided critical ground truth on Moon's plasma environment. Discovered electron densities significantly exceed orbital estimates, identified molecular ions in near-surface plasma. Entered sleep mode Sept 4, 2023; revival attempts Sept 22, 2023 unsuccessful.

items.description: Tetrahedral fluxgate magnetometer array for measuring lunar magnetic anomalies

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 8 to TRL 6. Mission scheduled for 'no earlier than 2026' on IM-3/Intuitive Machines (not 2024 as previously stated). Rover delivered to APL August 2023 for integration. Instrument built and delivered but NOT yet flight-proven. Verified from JHU APL official mission page.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. System includes 0.5m mast, four Bartington Mag566 sensors (tetrahedral array), and one science-grade dual-ring core fluxgate. Individual Mag566 sensors are miniature (20mW each) but total VML system mass not specified in accessible sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not fully specified. Individual Bartington Mag566 sensors consume 20mW each. Four sensors = 80mW minimum, plus primary sensor and electronics. Total system power likely <1W but exact value not published. Checked Bartington vendor site and JHU APL sources.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. JHU APL instrument for NASA CLPS/PRISM program. Government-funded research instrument.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable. Custom research instrument for specific NASA mission.

capabilities.value: Tetrahedral array of four commercial Bartington Mag566 fluxgate magnetometers (±100μT range, DC-30Hz bandwidth, 20mW each, ±5V supply) mounted at bottom of 0.5m mast, science-grade dual-ring core fluxgate magnetometer at mast top, sophisticated gradiometry separates lunar field from lander-generated fields, measures magnetic field during descent from 30km altitude and during surface operations, characterizes Reiner Gamma magnetic anomaly structure and mini-magnetosphere
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified and enhanced from EGU 2024 abstract and Bartington Mag566 specifications. Bartington sensors are MIL-STD-810F drop tested and space-qualified for this mission. Heritage from commercial magnetometer line adapted for space use.

items.notes: Part of Lunar Vertex mission to Reiner Gamma. Investigates magnetic anomaly origin and mini-magnetosphere structure. Uses commercial Bartington sensors.

items.description: Ion and electron velocity distribution spectrometer for lunar plasma environment

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 8 to TRL 6. Instrument delivered to lander integrator July 2023. Mission scheduled 2026 on IM-3/Intuitive Machines Lunar Vertex. Built and delivered but NOT yet flight-proven. Verified from SwRI official press release.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Verified as '11 pounds (five kilograms)' from SwRI official press release. Added from null.

power_kw.verification_notes: Verified as 'less than 6 watts' (0.006 kW) from SwRI official press release. Added from null.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. SwRI instrument for NASA CLPS/PRISM program. Government-funded research instrument.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable. Custom research instrument for specific NASA mission.

capabilities.value: Measures ion and electron velocity distributions with field of view 292.5° x 90°, energy range 8 eV/e to 17.5 keV/e, resolution more than 4x higher than typical Earth/Moon orbiting instruments, separates charged particles by energy and direction creating 3D pictures of particle behavior, characterizes solar wind interaction with lunar surface and localized magnetic fields at Reiner Gamma, determines if solar wind reaches surface within magnetic anomaly, heritage from ESA Rosetta mission spectrometer (comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko)
capabilities.verification_notes: Verified and enhanced from SwRI official press release. Lead Investigator: Dr. Jörg-Micha Jahn (SwRI). Heritage from ESA Rosetta mission to comet 67P. Development described as 'fastest turnaround of any space science instrument built by SwRI'. Works complementary to VML magnetometer.

items.notes: Part of Lunar Vertex lander payload. Studies interaction between solar wind and Reiner Gamma magnetic anomaly. Lead Investigator: Dr. Jörg-Micha Jahn (SwRI). Heritage from ESA Rosetta mission. Delivered July 2023, mission 2026.
